subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... But that is why I want to use IPA to describe the letters. You gloss over this difference, but when the manual is so wrong about something so simple, it is
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>


>
> It does now for most people. But in Read's day, /I/ was the preferred
> sound, and /i/ was either lower-class or American. Some Americans,
> for that matter, still have /I/: Jimmy Carter pronounces his name
> Jay-It-May-It, with the two syllables rhyming perfectly.
>
> Fortunately, it makes no great difference which one you use, because
> although /I/ and /i/ contrast when stressed, when unstressed the
> distinction is neutralized, just as it is before "ng" -- there are no
> minimal pairs. Read is merely suggesting standardizing on It because
> that was the more prestigious pronunciation at the time.

But that is why I want to use IPA to describe the letters. You gloss
over this difference, but when the manual is so wrong about something so
simple, it is certainly the best argument I have sen for my proposal.
Certainly we should not make the mistake that Read made in describing
the letter in terms of other letters. That just re-creates the problem.


>
> ("Sight reading"; an excellent example of a useless TO distinction!)
> I posted on this yesterday: TO is sort of cross-dialectal, but the cost
> is still much higher than it should be. We could make modest changes
> to TO that got rid of a lot of its problems without going all the way
> to phonemic (still less phonetic) orthography and a whole new script,
> for that matter.
>

Do you use QS yourself? If so, how much?

Paul
